metadata.title: 5 Ways Python is Better Than Julia | by Emma Boudreau | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 5 Ways Python is Better Than Julia
metadata.description: Python is the most popular high-level programming language in the world. This is for good reason, as a lot of code-bases are actually written inside of Python. Python is an interpreted high-level…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: here’s the counter I did to this one where I describe the 5 ways I think Julia is better than Python

all_paragraphs: Python is the most popular high-level programming language in the world. This is for good reason, as a lot of code-bases are actually written inside of Python. Python is an interpreted high-level programming language written in C. Julia, on the other hand. Python has surged further into popularity with Data Scientists in recent years, prior to Julia coming on the scene.

Julia is a high-level, multi-paradigm statistical programming language. Unlike Python, Julia was created primarily for statistical computing (like R.) Julia is a compiled language that uses its own compiler, dubbed the “ Just In Time” compiler. Although Julia is a great language to do machine-learning with, Python is still exceedingly popular in comparison.

The biggest upside to a Python-based project is that Python is a universal language, especially now in 2020. Lots of languages have been made to translate Python code, and the code is frequently used in many different industries, including, but not limited to:

Another massive benefit to Python’s popularity is documentation, as typically it is easier to find an answer to your question if somebody on the internet has asked it before. A big problem with Julia is lack of information, often you’ll find yourself reading terrible Github-README documentation. Needless to say, that can get pretty old after a while.

It’s no secret that Python is easy, and that’s a big plus. Let’s face it, complex algorithms with loss-functions and correlation coefficients being flung around is complex enough without having to worry about low-level syntax. Even writing the same code into Lisp, for example, can take upwards of double the amount of time. This comes with the benefits of quick education, quick understanding, and most of all quick troubleshooting.

Consequential to Python’s massive number of users is Python’s massive number of packages. What I really enjoy about working in Python is being able to use undocumented endpoints from a Python wrapper that someone made two years ago on Github. Things like this don’t exactly exist in Julia, and it can make getting data even harder.

Packages are a really important part of a language. Without the proper code-base to support machine-learning, you run into a lot of issues where you have to work things out from a very very low level. This is of course tedious, and consumes more time as it is being done. What’s fun about Python is being able to grab any tool out of your toolbox at a moments notice — without having to go program that tool for yourself to use.

It’s no secret that Python and Linux go hand and hand. This information can in fact be validated just with the realization that Python was originally published under a GPL license, and of course remains open-source to this day. This is great, because it means that all of our servers, Linux-based computers, and even Apple devices are now coming with Python pre-installed with default folders ready to go.

Another circumstance that this applies to is customization, as well as fixes. Don’t like how your Gnome applications bar doesn’t go away when it’s not in use? Well, program that in! Anything you don’t like is entirely programmable in one of the easiest languages to learn available.

Julia is a very versatile language, but with that being said, Python is versatile in an entirely different way. Python was created for object-oriented and general purpose programming (though not particularly found in any one of those paradigms.) This means that while Python has proven its ability in statistics and machine-learning, Python is also able to run APIs, move files, serve GUIs, host web-servers, control microprocessors, pretty much anything you want to do that’s above kernel level Python can do. This, of course, makes Python incredibly versatile.

Comparing Python’s versatility to Julia’s versatility, Julia’s usefulness certainly deteriorates at the lower-level. Not such a big deal, as low-level programming isn’t really going anywhere in the future, and an additional language to that is beating a dead horse, but in particular, Julia can’t do GUIs (not natively right now at least,) and has an arduino package — but has a hard time registering bus inputs. However deploying web-servers, statistics, and lower-level file-system work like writing text files is certainly still viable.

Julia and Python are both great languages that I love so much. Both languages definitely trade blows when it comes to the better of the two for data science. If you’d like to read a similar article from the Julia side of things, here’s the counter I did to this one where I describe the 5 ways I think Julia is better than Python. I can’t wait to see the future of Julia’s path and where Data Science languages will be in 10 years.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
